_link.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of alkali metals

toLevel2.question: Which group of the periodic table contains the alkali metals?

options.text: Group 1
Group 2
options.explanation: Group 2 contains the alkaline earth metals, not the alkali metals.

options.text: Group 17
options.explanation: Group 17 contains the halogens; alkali metals are in Group 1.

options.text: Group 18
options.explanation: Group 18 contains the noble gases; alkali metals are in Group 1.

toLevel2.question: How many valence electrons do alkali metals have?

options.explanation: 2 valence electrons belong to Group 2 elements; alkali metals in Group 1 have 1.
7 valence electrons belong to Group 17 (halogens); alkali metals have 1.
8 valence electrons belong to noble gases (Group 18); alkali metals have 1.

toLevel2.question: What happens when lithium is placed in water?

options.text: It fizzes and moves around on the surface, producing hydrogen gas
It sinks to the bottom and nothing happens
options.explanation: Lithium floats (density 0.53 g/cm³) and reacts with water, producing fizzing.

options.text: It dissolves like sugar with no reaction
options.explanation: Lithium chemically reacts with water, producing hydrogen gas and lithium hydroxide.

options.text: It turns the water into ice
options.explanation: The reaction is exothermic (produces heat), not endothermic.

toLevel2.question: Which property is typical of alkali metals?

options.text: They are soft enough to cut with a knife
They are very hard and difficult to scratch
options.explanation: Alkali metals are unusually soft for metals; they can be easily cut with a knife.

options.text: They are all gases at room temperature
options.explanation: Alkali metals are solids at room temperature, though they have low melting points.

options.text: They are all very dense and heavy
options.explanation: Alkali metals have low densities; lithium, sodium, and potassium float on water.

toLevel2.question: What charge ion do alkali metals form?

options.text: +1 (they lose their one valence electron)
-1 (they gain one electron)
options.explanation: Metals lose electrons; alkali metals lose their 1 valence electron to form +1 ions.

options.text: +2 (they lose two electrons)
options.explanation: Alkali metals have only 1 valence electron and lose it to form +1 ions.

options.text: 0 (they do not form ions)
options.explanation: Alkali metals are very reactive and readily form +1 ions.

toLevel2.template: Alkali metals are in Group {{blank:1}} and have {{blank:2}} valence electron(s).
Alkali metals are {{blank:1}} enough to cut with a knife and have {{blank:2}} melting points compared to most metals.
When alkali metals react with water, they produce a metal {{blank:1}} and {{blank:2}} gas.

toLevel2.statement: Alkali metals must be stored in oil because they react with air and water.
toLevel2.explanation: Alkali metals are so reactive they oxidise in air and react vigorously with water, so they are stored under oil.

toLevel2.statement: Alkali metals are found naturally in their pure elemental form.
toLevel2.explanation: Alkali metals are too reactive to exist naturally in pure form; they are found in compounds.

toLevel3.question: When sodium reacts with water, the products are sodium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. What is the word equation?

options.text: Sodium + water → sodium hydroxide + hydrogen
Sodium + water → sodium oxide + hydrogen
options.explanation: Sodium reacting with water produces sodium hydroxide, not sodium oxide.

options.text: Sodium + water → sodium chloride + hydrogen
options.explanation: Sodium chloride requires chlorine; the reaction with water produces sodium hydroxide.

options.text: Sodium + water → sodium + hydrogen + oxygen
options.explanation: Sodium is consumed in the reaction; the products are sodium hydroxide and hydrogen.

toLevel3.question: How does the reactivity of alkali metals change going down Group 1?

options.text: Reactivity increases down the group
Reactivity decreases down the group
options.explanation: Alkali metals become more reactive going down Group 1 as the valence electron is easier to lose.

options.text: Reactivity stays the same throughout the group
options.explanation: Reactivity clearly increases; potassium reacts much more vigorously than lithium.

options.text: Reactivity first increases then decreases
options.explanation: Reactivity consistently increases going down Group 1.

toLevel3.question: Why does potassium react more vigorously with water than sodium?

options.text: Because potassium's valence electron is further from the nucleus and easier to lose
Because potassium has more valence electrons than sodium
options.explanation: Both have 1 valence electron; potassium's is further from the nucleus so easier to remove.

options.text: Because potassium is heavier so it reacts faster
options.explanation: Mass does not determine reactivity; the distance of the valence electron from the nucleus does.

options.text: Because potassium has fewer electron shells
options.explanation: Potassium has more shells (4) than sodium (3), which is why its valence electron is easier to lose.

toLevel3.question: What is observed when potassium reacts with water?

options.text: It floats, moves rapidly, produces a lilac flame, and may cause a small explosion
It sinks and slowly dissolves
options.explanation: Potassium floats (density 0.86 g/cm³) and reacts vigorously, often catching fire with a lilac flame.

options.text: It fizzes gently on the surface with no flame
options.explanation: That description fits lithium; potassium reacts much more vigorously and usually ignites.

options.text: Nothing happens because potassium is unreactive
options.explanation: Potassium is highly reactive and reacts vigorously with water.

toLevel3.question: When a freshly cut piece of sodium is exposed to air, its shiny surface quickly turns dull. Why?

options.text: Because sodium reacts with oxygen in the air to form a layer of sodium oxide
Because sodium evaporates when exposed to air
options.explanation: Sodium is a solid metal that does not evaporate; it oxidises (reacts with oxygen).

options.text: Because sodium absorbs light and becomes dark
options.explanation: The dulling is a chemical reaction forming sodium oxide, not a change in light absorption.

options.text: Because the knife removes the shiny layer permanently
options.explanation: Cutting reveals a fresh shiny surface that then tarnishes due to reaction with air.

toLevel3.question: Alkali metals have low melting points compared to other metals. Which correctly ranks them?

options.text: Lithium has the highest melting point and caesium has the lowest in Group 1
Caesium has the highest melting point and lithium has the lowest
options.explanation: Melting point decreases down Group 1; lithium has the highest and caesium the lowest.

options.text: All alkali metals have the same melting point
options.explanation: Melting points decrease going down the group as metallic bonds weaken.

options.text: Sodium has the highest melting point in Group 1
options.explanation: Lithium, at the top of the group, has the highest melting point.

toLevel3.template: Reactivity {{blank:1}} down Group 1 because the valence electron gets {{blank:2}} from the nucleus.
The word equation for the reaction of potassium with water is: potassium + water → potassium {{blank:1}} + {{blank:2}}.
Melting points {{blank:1}} down Group 1, which means {{blank:2}} has the lowest melting point of the common alkali metals.

toLevel3.statement: Lithium reacts more vigorously with water than potassium.
toLevel3.explanation: Potassium is more reactive than lithium because its valence electron is further from the nucleus and easier to lose.

toLevel4.question: A student observes three alkali metals reacting with water: Metal A fizzes gently, Metal B fizzes and melts into a ball, Metal C catches fire with a lilac flame. Identify the metals in order A, B, C.

options.text: A = lithium, B = sodium, C = potassium
A = potassium, B = sodium, C = lithium
options.explanation: Vigour increases down the group: lithium is gentlest, potassium ignites with a lilac flame.

options.text: A = sodium, B = lithium, C = potassium
options.explanation: Lithium fizzes most gently, sodium melts into a ball, and potassium catches fire.

options.text: A = lithium, B = potassium, C = sodium
options.explanation: Potassium is more reactive than sodium; potassium catches fire, not sodium.

toLevel4.question: When sodium reacts with chlorine gas, the product is sodium chloride. Write the word equation and identify the type of bonding in the product.

options.text: Sodium + chlorine → sodium chloride; ionic bonding (Na⁺ and Cl⁻)
Sodium + chlorine → sodium chloride; covalent bonding
options.explanation: Sodium chloride is an ionic compound; sodium transfers its electron to chlorine.

options.text: Sodium + chlorine → sodium chlorate; ionic bonding
options.explanation: Sodium plus chlorine gas produces sodium chloride, not sodium chlorate.

options.text: Sodium + chlorine → sodium chloride; metallic bonding
options.explanation: Sodium chloride is an ionic compound, not a metallic one.

toLevel4.question: Rubidium is below potassium in Group 1. Predict what happens when rubidium is placed in water.

options.text: It reacts even more vigorously than potassium, likely exploding, producing rubidium hydroxide and hydrogen
It reacts less vigorously than potassium because it is heavier
options.explanation: Reactivity increases down the group; rubidium is more reactive than potassium despite being heavier.

options.text: It does not react because rubidium is too stable
options.explanation: Rubidium is highly reactive, even more so than potassium.

options.text: It fizzes gently like lithium
options.explanation: Rubidium reacts much more vigorously than lithium or even potassium.

toLevel4.question: Universal indicator is added to the water after an alkali metal has reacted. What colour would the indicator turn and why?

options.text: Purple/blue, because the metal hydroxide produced is an alkaline solution with a high pH
Red, because the reaction produces an acid
options.explanation: Metal hydroxides are bases (alkalis), not acids; the solution is alkaline.

options.text: Green, because the solution is neutral
options.explanation: The metal hydroxide makes the solution alkaline, not neutral.

options.text: Yellow, because hydrogen gas changes the indicator colour
options.explanation: Hydrogen gas escapes; the indicator responds to the dissolved hydroxide, which is alkaline.

toLevel4.question: Why are alkali metals stored under oil rather than in sealed containers of air?

options.text: Because they react with both oxygen and moisture in air; oil prevents contact with both
Because oil makes them easier to handle
options.explanation: Oil storage is primarily to prevent reaction with air and moisture, not for handling convenience.

options.text: Because alkali metals dissolve in oil
options.explanation: Alkali metals do not dissolve in oil; oil simply acts as a barrier to air and water.

options.text: Because sealed containers of air would be sufficient
options.explanation: Even sealed containers may contain enough oxygen and moisture to cause oxidation over time.

toLevel4.question: Lithium has a melting point of 181°C, sodium 98°C, and potassium 63°C. Explain the trend.

options.text: Melting point decreases because the metallic bonds weaken as atomic radius increases and the delocalised electrons are further from the nuclei
Melting point decreases because the atoms get lighter going down the group
options.explanation: Atoms get heavier going down the group; the decrease is due to weaker metallic bonds.

options.text: Melting point decreases because there are fewer protons in each atom
options.explanation: There are more protons going down the group; weaker bonding is due to larger atomic size.

options.text: Melting point decreases because the metals become less dense
options.explanation: Density generally increases down Group 1; melting point decreases due to weaker metallic bonds.

toLevel4.question: The reaction of lithium with water is: 2Li + 2H₂O → 2LiOH + H₂. How many moles of hydrogen gas are produced from 2 moles of lithium?

options.text: 1 mole of hydrogen gas
2 moles of hydrogen gas
options.explanation: The equation shows 2 moles of Li produce 1 mole of H₂ (2:1 ratio).

options.text: 0.5 moles of hydrogen gas
options.explanation: The stoichiometry is 2Li : 1H₂, so 2 moles of Li gives 1 mole of H₂.

options.text: 4 moles of hydrogen gas
options.explanation: The balanced equation shows a 2:1 ratio of Li to H₂.

toLevel4.template: When alkali metals react with chlorine, they form metal {{blank:1}} with {{blank:2}} bonding.
The solution produced when alkali metals react with water is {{blank:1}}, which turns universal indicator {{blank:2}}.
Metallic bond strength {{blank:1}} down Group 1 because the atomic radius {{blank:2}}, weakening the attraction between positive ions and delocalised electrons.

toLevel5.question: A student says: 'Alkali metals are stored under oil because they react with water, not air.' Evaluate this statement.

options.text: Partially correct; alkali metals react with both water vapour and oxygen in air, so oil protects against both, not just water
Completely correct; alkali metals only react with water
options.explanation: Alkali metals also react with oxygen to form oxides, which is why freshly cut surfaces tarnish.

options.text: Completely wrong; alkali metals only react with oxygen
options.explanation: They react with both water and oxygen; the student is partly right about water.

options.text: Wrong; oil storage is just tradition and serves no chemical purpose
options.explanation: Oil storage serves the important purpose of preventing reaction with air and moisture.

toLevel5.question: Sodium reacts with water much less vigorously than potassium. However, if you increase the amount of sodium used, can you make it react as vigorously as a small piece of potassium? What does this tell us about reactivity?

options.text: Using more sodium increases the total reaction but not the intrinsic reactivity per atom; reactivity is a property of the element, not the amount used
Yes; more sodium means higher reactivity
options.explanation: More sodium increases the total energy released but each atom still reacts with the same vigour.

options.text: No; the amount of metal has no effect on the reaction
options.explanation: More metal produces a larger reaction, but the reactivity per atom remains the same.

options.text: Yes; this proves sodium and potassium have the same reactivity
options.explanation: Potassium atoms individually react more vigorously; amount does not change intrinsic reactivity.

toLevel5.question: Francium is at the bottom of Group 1 but is radioactive and extremely rare. Based on group trends, predict its properties.

options.text: Most reactive alkali metal, lowest melting point, softest, and would react explosively with water
Least reactive because it is the heaviest and most stable
options.explanation: Heavier alkali metals are more reactive, not less; francium would be the most reactive.

options.text: Similar properties to lithium because both are at extremes of the group
options.explanation: Being at opposite ends of the group means opposite extremes of properties, not similar.

options.text: It would be a gas at room temperature because melting points decrease down the group
options.explanation: While melting points decrease, the trend suggests francium would still be solid (predicted mp ~27°C).

toLevel5.question: Compare the reaction of sodium with water (produces NaOH + H₂) and sodium with chlorine (produces NaCl). In both reactions, what is common about sodium's behaviour?

options.text: In both reactions, sodium loses its one valence electron to form Na⁺; the difference is what accepts the electron
In both reactions, sodium gains electrons
options.explanation: Sodium always loses its valence electron; it is always oxidised in these reactions.

options.text: The reactions are completely different with no similarities
options.explanation: Both involve sodium losing its valence electron; the other reactant differs.

options.text: In both cases, sodium acts as a non-metal
options.explanation: Sodium always acts as a metal, losing electrons in both reactions.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that caesium would be safe to handle because it is at the bottom of Group 1 and trends show metals become softer. Evaluate this reasoning.

options.text: Dangerously wrong; while caesium is soft, the increased reactivity means it reacts explosively with water and ignites in air, making it extremely hazardous
Correct; softer metals are safer to handle
options.explanation: Softness does not relate to safety; caesium's extreme reactivity makes it one of the most dangerous metals to handle.

options.text: Partially correct; caesium is safe if you wear gloves
options.explanation: Caesium reacts explosively with moisture; gloves alone are insufficient protection.

options.text: Wrong because caesium is actually very hard
options.explanation: Caesium is indeed very soft; the error is in assuming softness means safety.

toLevel5.question: Lithium's flame test colour is red, sodium is yellow, and potassium is lilac. How does flame colour help distinguish between alkali metals that otherwise look similar?

options.text: Each element produces a unique flame colour when its electrons are excited and then release specific wavelengths of light, allowing identification
The flame colour comes from the metal burning; hotter metals produce different colours
options.explanation: Flame colours are due to electron energy transitions, not combustion temperature.

options.text: The flame colour depends on the size of the metal piece used
options.explanation: Flame colour is characteristic of the element regardless of sample size.

options.text: Flame colours are random and cannot be used for identification
options.explanation: Flame colours are highly specific and are a standard method of identifying alkali metals.

toLevel5.question: Why are alkali metals not representative of typical metals? Give evidence from their properties.

options.text: They have low densities, low melting points, and are soft, unlike typical metals which are dense, high-melting, and hard; this is because they have only one valence electron forming weak metallic bonds
They are representative of typical metals in every way
options.explanation: Most metals are hard, dense, and have high melting points; alkali metals are exceptions.

options.text: They are atypical only because they are shiny
options.explanation: Shininess is a common metallic property; it is their softness, low density, and low melting points that are atypical.

options.text: They are atypical because they do not conduct electricity
options.explanation: Alkali metals do conduct electricity; they are atypical in density, hardness, and melting point.

toLevel5.question: In the reaction 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂, the hydrogen gas can be tested with a burning splint. What result would you expect and what does it confirm?

options.text: A squeaky pop, confirming the gas produced is hydrogen
The splint would be extinguished, confirming carbon dioxide
options.explanation: Carbon dioxide is not produced; hydrogen gives a squeaky pop with a burning splint.

options.text: The splint would glow brightly, confirming oxygen
options.explanation: Oxygen relights a glowing splint; hydrogen produces a squeaky pop.

options.text: Nothing would happen because hydrogen is inert
options.explanation: Hydrogen is flammable and produces a characteristic squeaky pop when ignited.

toLevel5.template: Alkali metals have atypically {{blank:1}} densities and melting points because their single valence electron creates {{blank:2}} metallic bonds.
Flame tests can identify alkali metals because excited {{blank:1}} emit characteristic {{blank:2}} of light as they return to their ground state.
